context: Prologue — First real meeting with Maya Torres. The origin choice happens here.

lines.text: TORRES AUTO — 6:14 AM. The rain has stopped. Dawn is a thin orange line behind the skyline.
You fell asleep in the CRX. Your neck aches. The windshield is fogged. Something is tapping on the driver's window.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Hey. Sleeping Beauty. You're blocking my bay.
You wipe the fog and see a woman in a grease-stained tank top, arms crossed, coffee in one hand. She doesn't look amused.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: This is a garage, not a motel. You've got about thirty seconds before I call a tow.
You step out. The morning air is cold and damp. She looks at you, then at the CRX, then back at you.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: ...The hell happened to this thing?
She crouches next to the front wheel well, runs a finger along a cracked brake line. Pops the hood without asking. You watch her catalog every failure with surgical precision.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Blown head gasket. Warped rotors. Your intake manifold has a crack I could fit my thumb through. And is that... duct tape on the radiator hose?

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: You were driving this? On the street? At night? In the rain?
She shakes her head slowly, but there's something in her eyes. Not pity. More like... recognition.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Alright. I'll bite. What's your story? Why are you parked in front of my shop at six in the morning with a car that should be in a junkyard?

choices.text: I used to be somebody. Got burned. Now I'm back.
Never had anything. Figured I'd take it.

lines.label: maya_responds_fallen
lines.text: Maya's eyes narrow. She's reading you — the way you hold yourself, the way you talked about it. Past tense. 'Used to be.'

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Somebody. Got burned. Now you're sleeping in a CRX in front of a stranger's shop.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: I've seen that look before. People who had it all and lost it — they either quit or they come back twice as dangerous.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Which one are you?

lines.label: maya_responds_outsider
lines.text: Something shifts in Maya's expression. The hardness softens — just a fraction.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: 'Figured I'd take it.' Just like that, huh?

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: You know what? I respect that. No sob story. No excuses. Just hungry.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Hungry I can work with.

lines.label: maya_responds_ghost
lines.text: Silence. Maya stares at you for a long moment. Most people would fill the gap — explain, justify, backpedal. You don't.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Your business. Sure.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: I don't trust people without stories. Everybody's got one. The ones who won't tell it? They're either running from something or hiding something.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Either way — you're interesting. And I don't get a lot of interesting around here.

lines.label: the_deal
lines.text: Maya looks at the CRX again. You can see the gears turning behind her eyes.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Look. This car is a disaster, but the frame is solid. The engine... I can work with the engine. It'll take time and parts, but it's not dead yet.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Here's what I'm thinking. I need another pair of hands around the shop. Oil changes, tire rotations, the grunt work nobody wants to do.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: You work for me — mornings and afternoons. In exchange, I fix your car on my time. Parts are on me. You just put in the hours.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: There's a couch in the back office that's seen better days. You can crash there until you figure your life out. No charge. But I hear one complaint about the springs, you're sleeping in the car.

lines.label: maya_deal_response_direct
lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Ha. No negotiation? No 'let me think about it'?

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: I like that. You either trust easy or you've got nothing to lose. Either way — welcome to Torres Auto.

lines.label: maya_deal_response_suspicious
lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: What's in it for me? I told you. I need help around the shop. That's it.
She pauses. Something flickers across her face — a memory, maybe. Gone before you can read it.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Maybe I'm just tired of doing everything alone. Maybe I see something in that car that's worth saving. Take the deal or don't. I won't offer twice.
The question lands harder than you expected. Maya's jaw tightens. For a second, she's somewhere else entirely.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Someone took a chance on me once. Didn't have to. Changed everything.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Don't read too much into it. You're cheap labor with a busted car. That's the whole story.

lines.label: meeting_end
lines.text: She tosses you a shop rag and nods toward the garage bay.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Go get some coffee from the machine in the back. It tastes like motor oil, but it's hot. We start in an hour.
You walk into Torres Auto. The smell of oil, rubber, and old concrete wraps around you like a second skin. For the first time in months, something feels like a beginning.
